reviewText: ***Spoilers Ahead***Along with Wolf of Wall Street, this movie got such a great deal of hype, not to mention Oscar awards, that I figured I'd give it a shot. Just like with Wolf of Wall Street, I was quite disappointed by it. The story itself seemed to just jump around all over the place, flashing from scene to scene before the first one was finished. The characters as well seemed very uneven as well, making emotional leaps and nosedives all over the place without any real clear reason why.You have our two "leads", Christina Bale (who I can't take seriously anymore after Batman) and Amy Adams, that are very close one second, then hate each other the next, then are back in close again without any real explanations as to why. They are supposed to be very smart con artists, and yet they don't utilize any of their skills to get out of the jam, or even try to, until the absolute last five minutes of the movie. Not to mention their "chemistry" seemed more like distilled water as opposed to any kind of fiery heat. I honestly couldn't care less if they ended up with each other or not by the end of the movie. And as far as the "friendship" between Bale's character and Renner's character, I only have Bale's voice over to tell me about this, because other than when Renner's character discovers what Bale's really been doing do we see any real emotion regarding the relationship between these two. Oh yes, and we have the film opening things with a shot of Amy Adams' character being a stripper, something that is never even mentioned again. So my question is, why even bother telling the audience about it? It brought absolutely no weight to the movie and quite honestly I forgot about that tidbit about the character five minutes later. The same could be said about Bale's character. The movie opens with him talking about how he shattered windows so his father would get business for his glass company so he wouldn't get "taken" anymore. Exactly how was his father taken? It's never even explained. Was it done legally or illegally? And, of course, there's his dry cleaning business, which is essentially pointless to this movie other than being a set piece in the beginning for Amy Adams to have a fashion show. Even Bale's art scam was pointless, as it had nothing to do with the rest of the movie. Hell, the scam he and Adams come up with made absolutely no sense. It was never really explained. What exactly were their marks giving them $5,000 for to begin with. Was it an investment, was it supposed to be money laundering? We're never told.You have the FBI agent (Bradley Cooper) who is so obsessed with going higher and higher up the criminal food chain that the entire character becomes a cartoon. When he beats the living hell out of his boss because he wouldn't give him an incredibly expensive hotel room for a sting operation, and is then given accolades by his boss's boss instead of being thrown out of the Bureau and charged with battery, at that point the whole movie had jumped the shark. And that's not even talking about his inexplicable use of cocaine in one scene that is never even hinted at again, regardless of his manic behavior throughout the movie.Jeremy Renner did do a fine job in the role he was cast. The character seemed rather sincere and wasn't a typical dirty politician, which was just fine for this movie. I can't say I have any complaints about the character other than it and the actor were wasted on this film.Jennifer Lawrence was fine, I suppose, though instead of being conniving and sneaky in her own loud way, she seemed like she was either a sociopath or someone with bi-polar disorder. Seriously, I doubt you'd have much trouble convincing a judge, even one from the late 70's, that she was in no condition to take full-time custody of her child.Then there were the accents. I was actually ok with Adams' British accent. It wasn't great but it wasn't too terrible either. The problem I had is she was supposed to be from New Mexico and yet she would inexplicably shift into a New Jersey or New York accent when not using her British one. This is after, in the opening scenes, we hear her normal accent which sounds Midwestern. It just makes no sense. That and Alessandro Nivola, Bradley Cooper's boss's boss sounded like he was trying to do a Christopher Walken impression the entire movie.About the only thing this movie had going for it was wardrobe, and by that I mean having the two leading ladies (more Adams than Lawrence) wear outfits that showed off their curves to the utter maximum without being vulgar for the entire movie.Overall, I just found the movie to be pretty bad and find it very disheartening that this and Wolf of Wall Street are what is considered wonderful, powerful movies these days. It seems that the people in Hollywood really know their audiences now and know they can cram any kind of garbage down our throats, as long as their PR people tell us it's the finest cut of filet. Do yourself a favor and skip this one, or if you have to watch it make sure you don't pay a dime to see it, it's a waste of your money.

reviewText: I kind of love that this movie opens with the clever disclaimer ‘Some of this actually happened’ because it sets a tone that pays off, mostly, for this energetic and enjoyable romp from David O. Russell.  Russell is a director who has been getting a lot of flak over the past few years (and his past few films) for selling out; leaving his former eccentric formula of filmmaking for a more commercial and Oscary trajectory.  I honestly didn’t care too much either way.  The only Russell film that I really like is ‘I Heart Huckabees’, which is actually very different from any of his other films I’ve seen.  Granted, I haven’t seen ‘Flirting With Disaster’ (which I hear is a favorite among his fans) but I seem to find some kernel of something I dislike about all his films, sans ‘I Heart Huckabees’.Still, I was kind of excited about ‘American Hustle’.  I’ll admit, when the project was first announced I wasn’t very interested.  I liked some of the cast and was disinterested in the other half.  Bale and Adams are usually reliable presences, and while I was never a fan BEFORE ‘Silver Linings Playbook’, I became a fan of Jennifer Lawrence based on that spirited performance and her tactless charm.  Still, I kind of hate Jeremy Renner and find Bradley Cooper annoying.But then the trailer was dropped and it looked like such fun!For me, ‘American Hustle’ kind of feels like an eccentrically commercial film, so maybe this is the perfect lane for Russell, who obviously wants that Oscar.  I’m still shocked that this so heavily over-performed with Oscar (racking up TEN Oscar nominations) and yet failed to win a single award, but AMPAS is obviously responding well to Russell’s directorial direction, so I’m sure it’s only a matter of time.Like I said; I couldn’t honestly care less, but whatever.The film is loosely based the ABSCAM federal con-job of the 70’s.  I’m not entirely familiar with the real story, so I have no idea what of this actually happened, but this was intricately plotted fun, and while there are some plotting issues, this film mostly succeeds because of an ample cast and some sharp direction.  Yes, David O. Russell has some serious fun with this one; point to point.Here we have Irving Rosenfeld, a charismatic con man who gets himself in a sticky situation when he gets busted by an over ambitious FBI agent named Richie DiMaso.  Irving’s partner, Sydney, is pulled into Richie’s web of charm and while Richie’s grip on Irving and Sydney tightens with his proposition to them, she begins playing the field herself; turning tables with a subtle allure.  You see, Richie wants bigger names than Irving Rosenfeld, and so he offers Irving a clean slate if he helps entrap four big names.  He sets his sights on Carmine Polito; an ambitious New Jersey mayor looking to make a better life for the kids in his community.  With his passions and Irving’s persistence, the con is in place to make Richie a big name in his unit.But Irving’s crazy wife, Rosalyn, could ruin everything.The energy here is pretty great, and that is thanks to all the sharp editing tricks.  Some films really rely on those cuts to create the needed tone, and this one has that in spades.  I kind of found the dialog here really pedestrian, so while the whole plot unraveling and twists here and there were intriguing and wholly engaged, the dialog in some key scenes was just distracting.  Thankfully, actors like Jennifer Lawrence and Bradley Cooper knew how to take those ridiculous lines and make them feel soulful and spirited.  The cast all works really, and I was surprised with how much I really liked Jeremy Renner here (who was honestly best in show).  A lot of people balked at Lawrence’s high octane performance and her battle with the accent, but she was just so hilariously layered here.  Her confrontation scene with Adams, despite some shoddy dialog (seriously Russell?) was so human.  Adams’ accent work, although part of the film itself, was more distracting simply because it was so unbelievably uneven that I can’t imagine anyone would fall for it, let along an FBI Agent.But like I said, this was a lot of fun, and while I would have trimmed this down a tad, I can’t say that I want my time back.

You see all the awards it's been getting, amazing quotes from critics, and your expectations are set way too high. Then, when you actually see it, you're totally disappointed, and expected something much better. That's exactly what happened when I first saw "American Hustle". When busted by FBI agent Richie DiMaso (Bradley Cooper), he is obliged to work together with him to lineup the arrests of several other people including congressmen and mafia members.With awesome costumes and music choices that set you right in the time period, the movie is enchanting from the start. It may be a tad too long, but the cast of off-beat and interesting characters make up for that in the end. Christian Bale is certainly the standout, and seeing his performance a second time solidified that. Go in with a clear head, and you will most-definitely enjoy it. Rated R for language and sexual content, "American Hustle" is enchantingly good.

reviewText: I just watched "The Wolf of Wall Street" (TWOWS) -- a film that clocks in at just shy of three hours -- and then I watched "American Hustle" (AH) -- a film that clocks in at a little over two hours.  Guess which film seemed to have the longer running time to me?TWOWS runs at an incredibly frenetic pace, mostly due to the standard terrific performance by Leonardo DiCaprio.  Sure, after watching that other film, you might look at your watch and think, "Wow!  Where did the day go!" but it is such a fun ride that you really don't care.  On the other hand, AH just seems to crawl along at a snail's pace, and after awhile I just wanted to roll up into a ball and go into my shell.I will say that Christian Bale is fantastic, however.  When is he not?  I watched a bit of "The Machinist" the other night -- I've seen it in its entirety before, and I just wanted to see him in that film again to see if he was as good as I'd remembered -- and he might have even been better there, although it is a very close call.  He is such a versatile actor that he can move like a chameleon from one role to another and you might only recognize him after glancing at the credits.  The rest of the cast here is fine, of course, but it just seemed to me that this film is less than the sum of its parts; take each of the actors and he or she is very good to great, but add them together and something seems to be missing.But to be fair, I will admit that I've never much been a fan of scam/caper flicks in general. reviewText: David O. Russell just sounds like one of those 1970s directors, or maybe it’s David O. Selznick I’m thinking about, who was a great producer in the 30s and 40s of many Hitchcock films, "King Kong" and most notably "Gone with the Wind". So David O. Russell really doesn’t compare to Selznick other than the similarity of name and the fact that the big ‘O’ in the middle seems to signify an association with quality films and Oscar nominated and winning films.Russell has been flirting with Oscar trophies for 3-years now. First he directed "The Fighter", then "Silver Linings Playbook" and now he will most certainly be nominated for a third time for "American Hustle". He may not win again, but it would be a safe bet that at least one of the actors he cast in "Hustle" will walk away with trophy. While Bradley Cooper, Amy Adams, Christian Bale and Jeremy Renner were all outstanding in their performances, I’d have to admit, it was Jennifer Lawrence that plays the smaller role in the film and steals the scene every time she appears."American Hustle" is a throwback to when films about heists, swindles and double-crosses were the talk of the town. It’s the kind of film that tests your true love for cinema. As the film plays out and we swirl around in Irving Rosenfeld (Bale) and Sydney Prosser (Adams) a.k.a Lady Edith Greensly’s worlds, it’s like a test of patience. Irving and Sydney find themselves getting deeper and deeper into trouble and the movie is exhausting with the banter, plots and plans. Your head will be literally spinning just hoping to keep up with their mess. While it was slow moving and littered with a barrage of oncoming information, it’s exactly how you should feel watching the film, because it is exactly what Irving and Sydney are dealing with."Hustle" is a dance along the fine line that is right and wrong; survival and ruin. It is exactly what happens when a script, that should be nominated for an Oscar by the way, can either be mundane and boring or lifted above that by the performers of the roles. The performers in "American Hustle" do just that and then some. With humor and passion and great writing, you get caught up in the tornado of right and wrong, trying to figure out how to get off, just like Irving and Sydney.

reviewText: "American Hustle" has an opening so simple it's genius. An out-of-shape Christian Bale is seen adjusting and perfecting his comb-over for five glorious minutes after the words "Some of this actually happened," appear on screen. Nearly every character is driven by greed as their flaws only seem to compliment the storyline more and more as the film progresses. It's like adding gasoline to a raging wildfire; undisciplined and out of control yet attention demanding in absolutely every way.Irving falls in love with Sydney even though he's married to Rosalyn (Jennifer Lawrence) and has adopted her son and loves him as his own flesh and blood. The love triangle gets even more disfigured when Sydney starts messing around with Richie who blatantly disregards his fiancé. The film mostly takes place in the late 70s and relocates from New York to New Jersey once the main storyline kicks into gear. Gambling has just been introduced to the state of New Jersey thanks to Mayor Carmine Polito (Jeremy Renner); a man loved by everyone who just wants to rebuild Atlantic City but occasionally does shady things in order to what's best for the people.Like "Silver Linings Playbook," "American Hustle" features a dance sequence. One of the main differences is that dancing was used as a way for the characters to connect in "Playbook." The dancing felt very neat, Pat and Tiffany became more drawn to one another, and dancing was shown in this very positive light that made it seem like an art form. In "Hustle," the dancing is sweaty, the people are smarmy and rubbing up on one another, and the lighting makes you sick. The whole sequence smells of bathroom sex and you can practically taste it. Dancing in "Silver Linings Playbook" is like making love to someone you care about for the first time; it's tender and intimate but a little sloppy due to inexperience. In "American Hustle," the dancing is rough, it's sloppy, and it's between two people who not only barely know each other but have done it countless times before. It's like the beginning of car sex without the opportunity to finish.The cast really lets loose in the film. Bradley Cooper unleashes this savage side of himself you've never really seen before. Richie is a loose cannon. The character is so angry in a scary kind of way. Jeremy Renner portrays a character that seems very out of the box for a guy who has mostly portrayed weapon experts. Carmine has this Robin Hood trait to him; he deals with the mafia and the politicians so the people don't have to in hopes of expanding the economy of the city. He has a heart of gold and a face everyone loves. Jennifer Lawrence adds a few new highlights to how well she can play crazy, unpredictable, and manipulative. Christian Bale is able to transform himself yet again and is nearly unrecognizable as Irving Rosenfeld. Irving has this car salesman quality to him that you can't stand and makes your skin crawl, but he has a way of getting exactly what he wants.Seeing Louis C.K. with a fairly substantial role is quite a surprise though. However you will be left craving an ending to that ice fishing story he always starts and never finishes. Lastly, Robert De Niro only has a very small supporting role in the film, but it's easily one of the best roles he's done in years. It's exactly what the actor is known best for. You can feel the tension in the room during the meeting with him and are completely thrown off guard by what he has up his sleeve.David O. Russell has created this riveting world full of eccentric, well-rounded characters. "American Hustle" is a crime drama that is constantly engaging, hilarious, and stimulating. Christian Bale is sleazy perfection.

reviewText: Suggested by actual events of the Abscam sting in the 1970s, the FBI plans to setup and arrest corrupt politicians. How they get the officials and the professional con artists that help the sting operation are the basis of a nostalgic film.  As directed and co-written by David O. Russell (Silver Linings Playbook, The Fighter), American Hustle is an acting clinic highlighting a convoluted tale of men and women who are looking for a big score.In 1978, ambitious FBI agent Richie DiMaso (Bradley Cooper), forces con man Irving Rosenfeld (Christian Bale) and his mistress, Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams), to help arrange a con on white collar crime, specifically targeting corrupt politicians.  Richie wants to make a name for himself, and he is immediately attracted to Sydney and has designs on her beyond the con.  Starting with a local, beloved mayor, Carmine Polito (Jeremy Renner), high level political figures are drawn in, and there is the possible organized crime connection. Further, Irving’s wife, Rosalyn (Jennifer Lawrence), threatens to derail the sting.  As Richie’s grand plan comes together, things get more complicated and risky, and Irving and Sydney must rely on their skills to survive.These are very well etched characters.  Each has something to gain, and each has an angle to exploit, whether it’s Richie’s dreams of a big bust or Rosalyn’s threats to expose the operation.  Kindred souls and survivors, Irving and Sydney have mastered the art of deception and manipulation.  You feel a degree of sympathy for Irving despite his criminal past and his marital discord.  Not only does he love his women, but he tries to save a friend from jail.  Irving turns out to be someone to root for.  In fact the world is not black and white especially when an FBI agent breaks the rules and gets involved with one of the principals.  Carmine is the noble, elected official who truly believes in doing good for his community.  Just who are the good guys and bad guys? Just who is conning who?Memorable scenes include a catty confrontation in a women’s restroom, the faceoff between Richie and his beleaguered boss (played to great effect by Louis C. K.), and an incredibly tense meeting with a head mobster (Robert DeNiro in a lethal cameo).Acting is superior throughout as expected in a Russell ensemble with the principals at the top of their game.  Bale transforms his physical appearance as an overweight, balding schlep (a far cry from The Dark Knight’s Batman).  A sultry Adams (Doubt, Her) has a great time playing a kindred con artist with a British accent.  Cooper (Limitless, The Hangover) has a ball as the gung ho agent with a 1970s perm who will step over his boss to get his time in the sun.  Lawrence (The Hunger Games, Winter’s Bone) excels as the wife who exhibits a bold brashness in public which delights her onlookers but risks blowing the sting.There is liberal use of 1970’s pop songs which blend with the costumes and hair styles seamlessly.  The camera work is fluid and is reminiscent of early Martin Scorsese films. There is a very carefree attitude in the film’s look and feel which is consistent with this loose, uninhibited decade.A slice of the seventies with freewheeling hustlers and loose morals, at its core, American Hustle is a love story centering on Irving, an imperfect con artist and the women in his life.  The film is essentially a con within a con and keeps you guessing until the end.  Although the film’s narrative is not as tight as it could have been, Russell has sacrificed a tiny bit of substance for style.  Do admire this film for the many scenes that pit flawed characters against each other.  Acting does not get much better than this.

reviewText: Imagine a con-artist couple, Irving and Sydney.  They get busted by an FBI agent, Richie, who asks them to help him nab a mayor and a bunch of crooked politicians.  The scheme involves a fake sheik, thousands of dollars that no one wants to put up, the mafia, and Irving's unpredictable, manic-depressive wife Rosalyn.Sound like a slapstick comedy by way of Martin Scorsese?  It is, sort of.  David O. Russell's AMERICAN HUSTLE is an homage to a decade, and an attempt to hone in on some of the classic Scorsese vibe.  A bit too much, at times--the style seems a bit of a rip-off at times, especially when paired with the (admittedly great) soundtrack.  In fact, as good a director as Russell can be, this film is elevated by its script (courtesy of Russell and Eric Warren Singer, featuring fantastic dialogue, some true emotional grit, and a couple nice twists) and the acting.  Christian Bales gives a complex, nuanced performance, which slowly grows as we learn more about Irving.  Amy Adams is dynamite; Bradley Cooper makes his jerk FBI agent sympathetic (but not so much that we ever truly like hime); Jeremy Renner doesn't get a whole lot to do as a pawn in the scheme, but he's clearly having fun.  Aside from Bale, it's Jennifer Lawrence who steals the scenes; like Bale's, her performance grows in complexity as the film progresses.  Sure, she's playing an older character; but it was only when a friend brought it up that I realized she's just 3 days shy of being exactly 4 years younger than me.  Like Bale, who becomes a pot-bellied, balding schlub with a combover, she nailed it.Kudos also goes to a cameo appearance from a film legend that I won't ruin, because it was a genuine (and pleasant) surprise for me.AMERICAN HUSTLE is one of those films that screams, "Give me an Oscar!"  Perhaps David O. Russell is a little desperate at this point.  That being said, it truly is an enjoyable film, at parts funny, at parts dramatic.  It leans a bit on Scorsese's filmography (particularly GOODFELLAS), but the acting is top-notch, the script is solid, and the overall experience has a few nice thrills.  Maybe it's not worthy of 10 Oscar nominations (and no wins, another Scorsese comparison you can make), but it's certainly one of the better movie experiences out there.

reviewText: "American Hustle" is a laugh-out-loud funny, very clever, well-produced, well-acted movie about conmen, crooked politicians, and an FBI sting operation. I enjoyed it while I was watching it but it left me empty. I didn't care about any of the characters or the plot points. I wasn't rooting for anybody and I wasn't involved in anything. Ultimately "American Hustle" felt been-there-done-that to me, and gimmicky and shallow. It reminded me of a lot of previous films about lovable gangsters and conmen, like "Goodfellas," "The Sting," and "Guys and Dolls." Christian Bale as petty conman Irving Rosenfeld reminded me of Frank Sinatra as Nathan Detroit.The gimmicks begin as the movie opens. It opens on a shot of Christian Bale's fat and bloated stomach. Bale is famous for losing weight for his role in "The Machinist." Then he became buff and muscular for "Batman." For "American Hustle" Christian Bale gave himself a fat gut. His fat gut takes up about thirty seconds of screen time and Bale could have played the role without it. His gut took me out of the movie. I started thinking, not about the character or the plot, but about Bale's tendency to gain or lose weight for roles. I assume he's pushing for an Oscar. I felt manipulated.The plot is pretty pointless. A small time conman, Irving (Christian Bale) and his conwoman girlfriend Sydney / Edith (Amy Adams) are recruited by FBI agent Richie (Bradley Cooper) to snag crooked politicians, including the mayor of Camden Carmine Polito (Jeremy Renner). Irving's wife Rosalyn (Jennifer Lawrence) gets in the way and causes some comic mayhem. Robert DeNiro shows up as a dangerous Mafioso.The production values are very high. The costumes are outrageous: velvet tuxedos and open shirts revealing hairy chests and gold chains. Amy Adams and Jennifer Lawrence are all decked out and paraded like models. In "Night at the Museum 2" Amy Adams wore tight, flesh-colored jodhpurs. Everyone talks about her butt in that movie. In "American Hustle" she wears plunging necklines and slit skirts. Everyone will be talking about her breasts and legs.The direction is fluid and musical – you feel like you're on an amusing ride. 1970s pop hits make up the soundtrack and action is choreographed to fit the music.The movie is laugh-out-loud funny, funnier than some films billed as comedies. It's hard to tell what genre the film is meant to be, because there are scenes where characters are obviously in pain.The audience is conned as well as the characters onscreen. There is a surprise. The surprise felt pretty cheap to me. The surprise was executed not by cleverness, but simply by hiding information from the audience.The performances are all fun to watch and very strong. Problem for me was that each performance seemed to exist in its own world. Christian Bale is doing comedy and parody. He is mocking the character he plays, and low class conmen in general. Jennifer Lawrence is weak. She is pretty, pouty, and young, but I didn't catch any acting talent. Bradley Cooper, as the FBI agent, is intense and grating in his hyper ambition and lack of smarts and caution. reviewText: David O. Russell's Blast from the Past about the 1970's ABSCAM scandal resonates because it depicts an out-of-control government (here, the FBI) fueled by personal ambition and an addiction to surveillance.  Sound familiar?  The line between Right and Wrong is interestingly blurred, personified by an obnoxious and ambitious FBI agent played by Bradley Cooper, and a personally incorruptible but do-whatever-it-takes Camden, New Jersey mayor played by Jeremy Renner.  The heroes of the tale, Christian Bale and Amy Adams, con artists nabbed by Cooper to work for him as he attempts to bring down "corrupt" politicians, mafiosos, and whomever he else he can bust, are caught in the middle.  The moral ambiguity extends beyond the parameters of the script: Atlantic City was eventually developed as a tourist destination later in the 80s, despite the ABSCAM busts, but by sharks operating "legally" -- people like Donald Trump.  (At least the Mafia knew how to run hotels, unlike the Donald.)  The message here:  corruption is an important civic value.  Greasing palms is how things get done in this country.  The biggest threat to our way of life are ambitious True Believers like Cooper who would stop progress in the name of Truth, Justice, and the American Way.  By the way, movies like this don't win Best Picture awards, so no one should be surprised that it was shut out at the Oscars last month.  However, I think regular Americans, wearied by the nonsense on the news concerning government zealots spying on us in a non-Constitutional manner, are mature enough for this movie's message.The problem is the execution.  There are some plot holes.  How do Bale and Adams expect to continue loan sharking without getting killed by vengeful marks who never got their payout?  The con artists even set up shop in a building to do their sharking.  It makes no sense.  And how does Bale's gum-snapping, fingernail-blowing housewife (Jennifer Lawrence) know about Bale's affair with Amy Adams?  Adams arrives at a party and Lawrence, upon seeing her, instantly knows her to be Bale's paramour.  And yet the movie goes to some lengths to tell us that she never leaves the house and has no idea what Bale does outside their front door.  So how does she know?  Only the Cutting Room Floor knows, I guess.  (Or -- sigh -- the "director's cut" version.)  I'm harping on it because what happens between Lawrence and Adams in the party scene changes that scene and impacts the rest of the movie.  Beyond plot problems, the movie is simply out-of-control and over-the-top, in terms of costume design and performances.  Look, I remember 1978, and I didn't recall women walking around with cavernous decolletage down to the navel except in fashion magazines.  The men suffer worse.  Bale looks like he raided Captain Kangaroo's closet, and the complicated basketry on top of his head would only encourage people to not take him seriously as a wheeler and dealer.  Just because a movie is set in 1978 doesn't mean everyone has to look like they're refugees from Studio 54.  Most people back then dressed the way we dress today, except that the pants were a little more flared and men wore their hair a bit longer.  There were more floral designs on women's attire.  But really, that was it.  (Disagree?  Take a look at "Network" from 1976, for example.  Pretty normally dressed people there, and that was the very apex of the Disco Age.)  Oh well, I guess director Russell is not big on the whole "less is more" concept.Performances?  One thing is clear: Amy Adams has the best agent in Hollywood.  She has managed to be in almost every ensemble cast of Oscar-bait films in the past 5 years.  "Doubt" ... "The Master" ... who knows what-all.  And yet I can't cite one memorable performance from her in all those films.  She doesn't deliver here, either.  She's supposed to be playing a vamp with a past as a stripper, but she's just too wholesome to pull it off, and the tried-and-true waterworks are always at hand if all else fails.  I appreciated Jeremy Renner's work here (he's the mayor) if only because he was restrained in comparison to most of the rest of the cast.  Now -- ahem.  I know everyone loves this girl, but I'll risk the hate and suggest that if Jennifer Lawrence plays another role that's out of her depth, as here, she is going to wear out her welcome really quickly.  She's a 23-year-old kid playing a role designed for an actor in her mid-to-late 30s at the peak of her powers.  The kid has talent, all right, but it needs to be guided and restrained until she has more experience under her belt.  Russell fails Lawrence miserably by miscasting her in the role in the first place, and then by indulging her every whim -- his too, it would seem.  Christian Bale, at least, is wholly convincing once again.  What a great actor.  He is now mastering the art of understatement -- watch him after Cooper knocks off his comb-over.  Watch him again when he enters a dangerous scene and waves Cooper away from Adams with a pistol.  His performance is consistent and true to the character he plays throughout.  If only his wardrobe was as understated as he was!  Bradley Cooper, who is in many scenes with Bale, should've taken Bale's cue.  I've seen Cooper restrained in other films; all I can think is that he and Russell are friends before colleagues and therefore the actor unfortunately did whatever he liked.  The scenes where he tries to seduce Adams are truly cringeworthy, and there are several such scenes.  Time for a rom-com, Bradley.  Calm down.Finally, Louis CK almost steals the show from everyone as Cooper's dull bureaucrat boss.  Cooper:  "I'm going to come over there and BEAT YOU!"  CK:  "What?"  (Now THAT'S good screenwriting.)  He's humiliated, manipulated, and practically castrated, but he emerges triumphant anyway by trying to do the right thing.  If our government was staffed with more CKs and less Coopers, we'd all be a lot better off.  3 out of 5.

reviewText: American Hustle follows on director David O. Russell’s Silver Linings Playbook that proved to be a hit last year in 2012. American Hustle is more a madcap comedy as we follow two con artists Irving Rosenfeld (Christian Bale) and Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams) in the late 1970’s. Irving and Sydney are kindred spirits and deeply attracted to each other, as they play off of Irving’s business loan scam where he takes $5,000 from his clients and gives nothing back. He also sells art forgeries on the side to which Sydney adds some class by affecting a British accent and turning herself into Lady Edith Greensly. Sydney eventually discovers that Irving is married to a flaky blond named Rosalyn (Jennifer Lawrence) and the two women despise each other.  All is going remarkably well until Irving and Sydney are caught scamming by an FBI agent named Richie DiMaso (Bradley Cooper).Richie is not the sharpest tool in the shed gets wrapped up in Irving’s stories on how he conned people. Richie thinks that in the post Watergate 70’s he can make a name for himself by setting a trap for unwary crooked politicians. Only he needs Irving and Sydney as players to pull his scheme off. Richie picks the mayor of Atlantic City Carmine Polito as his victim, who needs to rebuild his city to get people into a newly built casino.  When bribery fails to lure Polito into Richie’s trap and Arab investor is invented and Abscam is born. Little by little, the scam becomes more complicated until the mob gets interested.American Hustle is fun to watch because one never knows what is coming next, and everyone is conning someone else. Christian Bale is excellent as Irving, someone who could convince you that it’s in your interest to hand over all of your money to him. He fits into the 70’s fashion with his hair piece and comb over hiding his bald head and his loud shirts and trade mark neckerchief. Amy Adams personifies the post-1960s "liberated” woman, with her loose filling clothing and lack of underwear. Her clothing gives Sydney a liberated and bold appearance that fits her character well. Jennifer Lawrence is wonderful as Irving’s manipulative wife, throwing insults at Sydney when they meet and almost blowing the scam by spilling some of the details to a mobster.  Bradley Cooper does a great job playing the ambitious but over reactive FBI agent who can barely control himself when it comes to ordering his boss to give him more money for the scam.  It was also good to see veteran actor Anthony Zerbe as Senator Horton Mitchell, brief as his part was.American Hustle is a brilliant caper film that keeps you guessing and has some very fine performances by a fantastic cast.

reviewText: This movie begins with the statement that 'The story is partially based on facts'. It is a fictionalized version of the Abscam case dating to 1980 in which the FBI and the rest of the Justice Department arrange a sting operation to trap a NJ senator and seven congressmen and other Jersey pols into accepting bribes to get a license for a gambling casino in Atlantic City. We are introduced to the con artists (Christian Bales & Amy Adams) assisting each other in selling fake art masterpieces to gullible citizens including the FBI (a separate sting) who have something on Adams and keep her in a bare room for three days in order to get her to get Bales to participate in the great sting. The FBI agent behind the sting, Bradley Cooper, is also a con man chasing Adams and conning his boss to get taxpayer money to set up the sting. An agent is dressed as an Arab prince who offers money through Bales to various pols starting with the Majority Leader of the NJ House, Jeremy Renner, who is portrayed as a 'good guy' only interested in supporting his community through casino-generated income, and, less clearly, Congressmen and Senators. But Renner takes money and serves his time in prison as did all the other pols.But why was a two-bit con man able to carry out such a sting? The movie suggests that it was greed on the part of the pols. This was emphasized by a cameo scene with Robert DeNiro playing a Mafia don who was offered a bribe and spoke Arabic to the agent playing the Arab prince who didn't understand him and couldn't answer in his presumed native tongue. All the pols in this scene should have recognized the sting but didn't.Two problems with the plot were the need to 'torture' Adams to get Bales to cooperate and the ending was somewhat unclear. The rumor was that the NYTimes was about to break the case, that someone had leaked information to the paper, and the sting had to be completed fast by getting an admission of bribe acceptance from… a lawyer who represented… whom? Nevertheless, the film ends with the principals living happily ever after and those stung paying their expected debt to society.
summary: Well acted but slightly flawed satire of the Abscam case

reviewText: AMERICAN HUSTLE (2013) is by far the best comedy-caper film I have seen in decades!The cast is uniformly excellent, the gags are genuinely funny, the dialogue is intelligent, and the plot twists are plausible but nearly always unforeseeable. And the film has a "good heart"! Non-traditional, unexpected kindness and generosity triumph and leave us feeling good at the end.Christian Bale sets the tone at the very start as Irving Rosenfeld, a world-class conman with a potbelly and the most amazing hair comb-over! Laughable as he is and crooked as he is, he and his partner-mistress Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams) are made sympathetic to us by their voice-over comments that reveal their backgrounds, their goals, and their high-functioning mental processes.Bradley Cooper is hilarious as Richie DiMaso, a hyper-ambitious curly-haired FBI agent, who lusts for Sydney Prosser and forces her and Irving to help him entrap an array of Congressmen and a New Jersey mayor (Jeremy Renner) with a bribe-offering sting called ABSCAM.Among many loose cannons, the biggest is Irving's wife Rosalyn (Jennifer Lawrence), who is receptive to the amorous advances of a powerful mobster. Will she reveal what Irving and the others are up to? Will she cause Irving to be harmed ...? Will she ...?And, as the film approaches its ending, two of the characters decide that they will take an all-new kind of control of the whole situation. And YOUR job may be to try to spot it as it happens ... IF it is happening. Or to spot it being derailed.As with that great comedy-caper film THE STING (1973; Robert Redford and Paul Newman), despite this explicit heads-up from these two characters, 999,999 viewers out of a million will be totally surprised by the outcome. But very pleasantly surprised if they've been paying attention.For me, the only factor that gives THE STING a very slight advantage over AMERICAN HUSTLE is its great musical score that featured those wonderful ragtime melodies of Scott Joplin.This film deserves a VERY strong "A+" grade.

reviewText: Most Hollywood films celebrate working class values and no film does that better this year than AMERICAN HUSTLE. What's weird about this movie though is that neither of the characters who are trying to do good are rewarded but both of the hustlers get exactly what they want: each other. Neither the Bale or Adams characters are loyal to their class (they'll hustle anyone) but they are ultimately loyal to each other. Bale is maybe the more sympathetic character (his schemes are just about money but he really doesn't want to hurt anyone) but the Adams character is far more mysterious, she hustles people not just for money but to prove something to herself -- to prove to herself that life is not determined by the accident of birth or class affiliation. Her roles are opportunities to explore her sexuality, intellect, imagination, and sense of play. To her the real is not some stable property/commodity with a fixed value but whatever you believe it is and get others to believe it is. Although the film like most other Hollywood films praises working class types, it undermines the notion that working class types are one-dimensional and/or incapable of participating not just in the American dream of social mobility but the even more compelling dream of identity mobility. Director David O Russell is clearly on the side of the working class and he loves showing working class types enjoying working class pleasures but in American Hustle he adds at least one new pleasure to the working class repertoir: the joy of conning people from the upper classes. At the beginning of the film Bale and Adams will con anyone regardless of class but by the end of the film they have affirmed their class loyalty and only after doing this do they seem to understand themselves and to be as merry if not as socialist as Robin Hood. American Hustle does play like a Scorsese film with one important difference: the racketeering raconteurs in America Hustle actually find a way to go legitimate (or at least as legitimate as any Modern "artist" can be). So what you have in American Hustle is the first existentially complex working class con dramedy. I'd give it a Globe.
summary: Existentially Complex Working Class Con Dramedy

reviewText: Those viewers with long memories might notice resemblances between David OI. Russell's film and George Roy Hill's THE STING.  In both works, the principal center of attention is on the psychology of conning; how people can render themselves perfectly plausible to their victims and get away with it.  However there is one important difference: whereas the earlier film took a jokey approach to the subject-matter (complete with Scott Joplin-inspired ragtime score), AMERICAN HUSTLE takes a long hard look at the lives of Irving Rosenfeld (Christian Bale) and sidekick Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams), and shows how their lives are fundamentally empty.  Although Rosenfeld protests his enduring love for his wife Rosalyn (Jennifer Lawrence), it's clear that his main focus of attention is on sustaining the con.  When it threatens to get out of hand, he tries to withdraw, but finds himself unable to do so.  Likewise Sydney; although she is a masterly impersonator of a British aristocrat, she has nothing much else to fall back on.  In the world of late 70s New York, it is every person for themselves - even the cop Richie DiMasso (Bradley Cooper) is out to exploit everyone around him.  In the end, Irving and Sydney come to a decision - the only way to extricate themselves from difficulty is to plan the ultimate con.  Their lives will not improve as a result, but at least they will be safe for a while.  AMERICAN HUSTLE is a long, controlled, brilliantly acted movie.  Director Russell's camera focuses on the protagonists in minute detail, taking a long hard look at their relationships, while suggesting that such relationships only work if the con works successfully.  If the con fails, then relationships come crashing down.  The late Seventies New York atmosphere is brilliantly evoked; the city is both attractive yet terribly seedy, a place where only the fittest survive.  The soundtrack, with hits from the period, only serves to enhance this mood.  This film has been nominated for several awards, and justifiably so.

reviewText: David O. Russell has become a household name in Hollywood and also amongst many avid moviegoers. While he’s had several projects over the years, he really bust on to the scene in 2010 as the director of The Fighter – which starred Christian Bale and Amy Adams, both of whom were nominated for multiple awards for their individual supporting roles (Bale won both an Academy Award and Golden Globe). Flash forward two years and that brings us to 2012 where Russell once again made his mark on the big screen by penning the script (originally created by Matthew Quick) and directing Silver Linings Playbook. The film starred Bradley Cooper and Jennifer Lawrence, both of whom earned several nominations for various awards of their own (Lawrence won both an Academy Award and Golden Globe). Now, here we are one year later as these four well-established actors star in Russell’s newest film, American Hustle.In American Hustle, Christian Bale stars as a con artist named Irving Rosenfeld. One day, he meets an attractive woman at a party named Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams), who he immediately falls for and brings in to his racket. Together, the two are so successful conning people (approving loans, selling fake art, etc.) that it attracts the FBI. Sydney, working alongside Irving under a false name, is busted and taken into custody by an ambitious agent, named Richie DiMaso (Bradley Cooper). In order to clear Sydney’s name, Irving and Sydney must work undercover alongside Richie to complete four major busts.Posing with the fake financial backing of the foreign Sheik Abdullah (Michael Peña), the trio goes into business with the crooked New Jersey Mayor, Carmine Polito (Jeremy Renner). The beloved, yet crooked Mayor has a vision of returning Atlantic City to prominence and also creating thousands of new jobs. However, in order to do so, he must secure finances – which means he is willing to partner-up with the mob. The backroom dealings with the mob also require a few acts of Congress, leading to the eventual bribing of a handful of Congressmen and one Senator. However, the only thing that can screw everything up is Irving’s wife, Rosalyn (Jennifer Lawrence), who has a flare for the dramatic and constantly requires attention.From the moment this film begins until the very end, it’s relatively safe to say there’s no film in the history of cinema that depicts this much hustling, cheating, and lying. In the event that any one of the characters walked into a church, it would positively go up in flames. Irving is hustling Sydney, and she loves him for it. Rosalyn is hustling Irving, and he hates her for it. Richie hustles Sydney and Irving, while Sydney is constantly hustling Richie. Richie and company are hustling the mob, the Mayor, and members of Congress – and the FBI is behind all of it. There is literally no one in this film that isn’t hustled at one point or another.To that end, you need accomplished actors and actresses that are capable of selling these onscreen hustles, and with that being said, there might not be a more perfect ensemble in the history of filmmaking than the four individuals featured in this film. David O. Russell clearly had the unspeakably brilliant epiphany to bring the four highly acclaimed cast members from The Fighter and Silver Linings Playbook together for one incredible feature. He even sneaks in (SPOILER) Robert De Niro from a perfectly timed cameo. And, the end result is a masterful work of art.Christian Bale is the focal point of this character-driven story. For whatever reason, Bale needed to be overweight and balding for the role and also suffers from a serious heart condition. However, before you jump to any conclusions, it should be noted that none of these elements are vital to the story. Bale’s character is too confident to let his physical appearance hinder his appetite for the hustle. And confident he most certainly is – proving he’s almost too good to be caught. He lives his life through one of the film’s most prudent themes: the art of survival.Jennifer Lawrence is obviously a huge star these days, especially since he roles The Hunger Games films, along with the X-Men films and Silver Linings Playbook. Those films are all fine and dandy, but they are targeted towards a particular audience and will likely succeed with or without her involvement. Lawrence proves her talent, not by shooting arrows at people, but by taking on serious, well-written dramatic roles. Once more, Lawrence steals each and every scene in which she’s present (mostly with her humorous nut ball comments) – and she does so with such elegance. Like her role in Silver Linings Playbook, she portrays a mentally disturbed individual with serious emotional distress. Even though she’s only present for a handful of scenes in this film, she’s still a main attraction, even despite the scene dominance of her wondrous cast mates.While it’s easy to see the outstanding performances of Christian Bale and Jennifer Lawrence, the impressive acting of Bradley Cooper and Amy Adams shouldn’t go unnoticed. Neither gives an over-the-top, career defining performance, but they are equally acclaim worthy. Cooper, more so than Adams, shows just how far he’s come in Hollywood – going from comedy to action and now fully establishing himself as a serious dramatic actor. Of course, Amy Adams is already a domineering presence in dramatic acting, so the fact that she puts on an amazing performance is no surprise at all. The scenes that Cooper and Adams share together are remarkably energetic, and are proof that despite what you may think you see, the hustle never ends. Never.Overall, it’s not surprising that so many have praised America Hustle as one of the top films of 2013. There’s little doubt this film tries to make hustling look cool – and it succeeds. It also doesn’t fail to make these ambitious characters look cool – with their flashy hair, scantily clad outfits, and smooth dialog. No, this film doesn’t have the satisfying payoff that you’d expect from a movie like Ocean’s 11, but it does prove that crime-centric films are still unbelievably entertaining. Obviously, there are drawbacks to seeing this film. Most notably, there is no action-packed shootouts or ridiculous CGI. American Hustle is simply a film where acting and character development come first, while everything else, like plot and tying up loose ends comes second. If drama is your fancy, this film will plain and simply knock your socks off.GRADE:  AFNDNreview.com

Loosely based on the Abscam, which for those who have forgotten, 'Abscam--sometimes written ABSCAM--was a Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) sting operation run from the Bureau's Hauppauge, Long Island, office in the late 1970s and early '80s. The operation initially targeted trafficking in stolen property but was converted to a public corruption investigation. The FBI, aided by a convicted con-man, videotaped politicians as they were offered bribes by a fictional Middle Eastern sheik in return for various political favors. The investigation ultimately led to the conviction of a United States Senator, six members of the United States House of Representatives, one member of the New Jersey State Senate, members of the Philadelphia City Council, the Mayor of Camden, New Jersey, and an inspector for the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service.' Given that bit of reality, Russell and cast and crew created a stingingly brittle yet funny movie.AMERICAN HUSTLE is set in the alluring world of one of the most stunning scandals to rock our nation. It tells the story of brilliant con man Irving Rosenfeld (Christian Bale), who along with his equally cunning and seductive British partner Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams) is forced to work for a wild FBI agent Richie DiMaso (Bradley Cooper). DiMaso pushes them into a world of Jersey powerbrokers and mafia that's as dangerous as it is enchanting. Jeremy Renner is Carmine Polito, the passionate, volatile, New Jersey political operator caught between the con-artists and Feds. reviewText: David O. Russell started out as a director with a vision; he made the incredibly challenging films SPANKING THE MONKEY and THREE KINGS, and as the years went on, he seemed to tire of making films with something to say, and opted for performance-based Oscar bait. Both THE FIGHTER and SILVER LININGS PLAYBOOK are not bad films in the least, but neither of them really do anything to subvert audience expectations. Either of those films could have been directed by just about anyone. AMERICAN HUSTLE has a little of the former and a lot of the latter, but toes the line just enough to keep you interested and invested, and for once with Russell's recent films, you don't know how it's going to end.AMERICAN HUSTLE is a highly fictionalized accounting of the real life Abscam scandals of the late 70's that involved some low to mid-level elected government officials as well as the Mob, and how it took a couple of con artists to teach the FBI how to properly catch them. You have Irving (Christian Bale) and his lover/partner Sydney aka Lady Edith (Amy Adams) as a great short-con artist team, as well as Irving's incredibly unhinged wife Rosalyn (Jennifer Lawrence) on the "family" side. But once Irving and Sydney are busted by young FBI agent Richie (Bradley Cooper), they're behind the eight-ball. But Richie has bigger fish he wants to fry. He's sick of government corruption and wants to go after those who want to use their elected positions to accept graft, and in Irving and Lady Edith, he sees an opportunity to learn what they have to teach. He agrees to drop the many fraud charges against them if they will assist him in four arrests, and they reluctantly agree. The first person Richie wants to go after is Carmine Polito (Jeremy Renner), the beloved family-man mayor of Camden, New Jersey. Polito seems to be looking to get funds to assist with the renovation of Atlantic City to help create thousands of jobs his constituents desperately need. Once it gets to a certain point, though, thanks in no small part to the emotionally manipulative Rosalyn and the increasingly desperate Richie, Irving and Sydney seem to have no way out of what they themselves have been manipulated into.Russell keeps the film at a really solid rhythm all throughout, and the actors, including Louie C.K. as Richie's FBI superior and a cameo by Robert De Niro as a feared Miami mob underboss, are all stellar. Bale continues to amaze with another chameleonic performance; Cooper gives what I would consider to be the performance of his career; Lawrence keeps hitting the bullseye film after film and is arguably the strongest actor of her generation and this performance is no exception; Renner gets past his misstep from being in HANSEL AND GRETEL: WITCH HUNTERS to being more on par with the performances he's given in the past. The strongest performer here for me is Adams, who always does incredibly solid work, but here, she's given a role within a role that she plays with gusto, intelligence, sexiness, and total confidence.My main complaint about this film, though, is how it really does seem to be Scorsese-lite. Many indie filmmakers seem to feel the need to ape Scorcese at some point in their careers, and while it works in this film, I would have liked much more to see a film that was more of Russell's and less of a 70's-era homage.All in all, AMERICAN HUSTLE is exciting and entertaining filmmaking that could have used a boost of originality, but let's face it: Russell seems to really just want to get that Oscar. Or if not him, than at least his cast.4.5 out of 5 stars.
summary: An extremely entertaining if somewhat played-out 70's-era style mashup.

reviewText: American Hustle is a disappointing chaotic and beautiful mess of a film with a plot that becomes convoluted with every con, twist and turn, and by the end you won't care about the plot, and leave the theater wondering what you just watched. American Hustle is thankfully saved by the excellent cast, and the eclectic cast of characters in the film.Yes I was a little disappointed with American Hustle, and the overall plot of the film. Thankfully what makes American Hustle such a good film are the actors and cast of characters. Christian Bale stars as Irving Rosenfeld a small time business man who owns a few dry cleaners, but makes most of his money as a con artist. The character is balding, overweight with heart problems, but doesn't let his limitations stop him from getting what he wants. It was a welcome change to see Bale in such a different role from the suave good looking dark knight Bruce Wayne, and Bale again shines as Rosenfeld. Just like Rosenfeld, Sydney Prosser is determined to escape her old miserable life as a stripper into Edith Greensly. Amy Adams is superb playing the dangerous, sexy, and complicated Sydney. While Rosenfeld and Prosser find love together a con artist is a con artist and will con even the people he or she loves like having an adopted son, and Rosalyn Rosenfeld a stay at home unhinged wife who is terrified of change. Now Lawrence was funny playing the fierce Rosalyn with raw and primal energy, and Rosalyn slowly grows throughout the film, but it wasn't Lawrence's best performance of her career, and not her best performance this year. Still even with it not being her best performance Lawrence still shines throughout the film, and is worthy of an Oscar nomination.As for the rest of the cast the majority of them gave good performances. Michael Peña was great playing a FBI agent who poses as Sheik Abdullah, and Robert De Niro was splendid in his brief role as Victor Tellegio. The only questionable acting choice or character in American Hustle was Jeremy Renner as Mayor Carmine Polito. While I like Renner, and know the character was necessary in the plot for Irving to come to some realizations the actor and character just didn't seem to fit, and left the role lacking throughout the film. I am somewhat divided on Richard DiMaso and actor Bradley Cooper. I know director David O. Russell loves to bring out the dark and crazy side of his characters displaying to the world that we're all have a few screws loose, but Russell and Cooper to DiMaso to the extreme as the FBI agent entraps Irving, and Sydney forcing them to help him nap other criminals. While at times laughed and really enjoyed Cooper playing the ambitious DiMaso the character could at times be off-putting and just plain annoying, but with the quality of acting, and Russell's directing these small flaws didn't keep me from enjoying the film.I guess I should speak briefly about the plot as that was what I had the biggest problem with while watching American Hustle. The film is very loosely based on events in the 1970's, and written by Eric Warren Singer and David O. Russell. The plot involving DiMaso using Irving, and Sydney to get an ever growing number of politician and criminals becomes more convoluted as the stakes get higher, and everyone is conning, and using each other to get what they desire out of the situation. reviewText: "American Hustle" (hereafter "AH") is a reasonably entertaining and engrossing variation of the sturdy "Small-Time Con Man is Pushed Into the Big Leagues" plot.  The small-time con man is the paunchy and sleazy-looking Irving (Christian Bale) with ratty hair that has a life of its own.  Irving gravitates toward scams and fraudulent businesses because he remembers the racketeers and hoodlums taking advantage of his glass-selling father, and wants to be the on the winning side.  Mainly he dabbles in selling art forgeries and using the proceeds to arrange phony loans to desperate customers.  Somewhat amazingly, he attracts the romantic attention of a sultry, slinky red-haired distaff con artist Sydney Prosser (alias: Lady Edith Greensly) (Amy Adams).  Together they stage more lucrative, but still relatively low-level scams.  Irving keeps Sydney as a mistress and comforting muse and morale-booster because he is married to shrill, maritally frustrated, and seemingly dense Rosalyn Rosenfeld (Jennifer Lawrence from the "The Hunger Games") and has a young son by her.  Almost inevitably, Irving and Sydney choose the wrong mark for one of their bogus art sales - excitable, eager, but somewhat meatheaded mama's boy Richard "Richie" Dimaso, FBI Agent.To avoid jail time, Irving and Sydney agree to help "Richie" orchestrate an "Abscam" inspired sting operation intended to expose at least four U.S. congressmen for bribery and, I think, violation of immigration laws since a "wealthy Sheik Abdullah" (actually Paco Hernandez) offers to fast-track his American naturalization process for a hefty fee.  Somehow, all this action also involves "slightly unscrupulous" New Jersey Mayor Carmine Polito (Jeremy Renner) and his desire to develop waterfront property businessess and casinos to help his constituents.  And that's the plot of AH.Besides the reasonable pleasure of watching the scams (and counterscams and double-crosses) unfold and unravel, AH also vividly and convincingly re-creates the outlandish and kooky zeitgeist of the '70s with well-chosen '70s song classics (like Steely Dan's "Reeling in the Years" and Wings's "Live and Let Die"), the occasional parties, and introduction of new gadgets like microwaves, which Rosalyn learns are hostile to aluminum foil.  Especially, AH does not forget the hair styles.  Irving isn't the only one with follicle trouble; his wife Rosalyn's 'do looks like yellow spaghetti; Mayor Polito has the Elvis pompadour; even FBI agent Richie (in a hilarious sequence) shows how he gets all the little curls in his hair as his mother yells at him to fix the fish tank filter. Richie's exasperated and brow-beaten FBI superior and mentor Stoddard Thorsen (Louis C.K.) provides some humorous bits as he tries to stop Richie from squandering funds on an entire hotel floor for the scam, and to relate and finish an ice-fishing experience he had with his brother as a kid. Jennifer Lawrence (as Rosalyn) is a hoot as the complaining "bubblehead" who nevertheless has valid objections against Irving's treatment of her and even advises him on a Plan B when one of his cons (can't remember which one) starts to go south.  From time to time, AH also provides voice-overs (mainly from Irving but sometimes from Sydney) explaining his philosophy, his motivation, and the movie's plot.Thus, AH has its positive qualities, but for me the movie stumbled somewhat because it fails to follow Irving's credo to work on small, simple cons.  The straightforward plot starts to wind back upon itself as cons get conned and counter-conned and players get played and counterplayed.  Robert DeNiro's fleeting and almost-stereotypical but expectedly effective portrayal of mobster Victor Tellegio wanting a piece of the "Sheik"'s action actually, I humbly think, needlessly complicates matters.  Eventually, at about the midway point, AH becomes, as another Amazon.com reviewer puts it, "yawny", and I momentarily lost track.  That was unfortunate for me, because the climax and denouement of AH, with some ironic turns and fates for characters we expected otherwise that the midway point might have explained.Overall, I generally recommend the movie and its various retroactive pleasures (including predicaments that could have been solved by cell phones and Internet access if they had existed in the early '70s), especially the funky coiffures.  But try to keep your attention focused, because AH's con goes on and on and on, and might leave you behind if you're not careful.3.5 stars
summary: The Con Goes On and On and On...and So Does the Hair!

reviewText: Ok. Yes, this is the third film in a row that I've reviewed that was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Picture. It's just that I've been having a marathon of some sort. Also of note is that the date this review is published befalls my birthday. Happy Birthday to Me! Even though I'm writing this a month or so in advance, it's still nice to write. 'American Hustle' was one of those Academy Award Best Picture nominees I most wanted to view myself. I'll be honest when I say that back in August 2013 when the first trailer for the film came out, I was not interested at all. And then later on I watched the second trailer and started to get interested. It's the costumes and cast that really got me attached. It looked like a film that puts you in the 70's and I'm glad to note it does. Now let's read my review of 'American Hustle'.'American Hustle' follows Irving Rosenfeld (Played by Christian Bale) a businessman who operates a small business of dry-cleaning shops. But Irving's greatest business success was as a con man operating a fake money lending scheme, to fool people into handing him 5,000 dollars for credits. He has a wife and child as well. After meeting and falling in love with Sydney Prosser (Played by Amy Adams), a big dreaming, smart girl, Irving asks her to join him in his operation. But the two are soon busted by senile and aggressive FBI agent Richard DiMaso (Played by Bradley Cooper) who forces the two to con the Mayor Carmine Polito (Played by Jeremy Renner) or face jail time. But things go too far with the two whining up attracting the attention of the mob.'American Hustle' is a very interesting film. But the most interesting thing is the characters. Some of them start out cool and end up being a steam pot. The characters are relatable and well fleshed out throughout the bloated 2 hours and 10 minutes runtime. Usually when you watch a movie, the characters are more of a side dish, with the action the main course, and it hurts the film in many ways. But this is obviously not the case with this film. We are given emotionally acceptable characters, characters you hate, characters you love. Highly realistic characters with motives for their actions and interesting back stories. We feel their desperation and anger and fear.Director 'David O. Russell' dives into this crime cape masterfully. Coming off the critical successes of 'Silver Lining Playbook' and 'The Fighter' O. Russell get's inside the story, delivering ripe camerawork and giving us hearty characters, characters that we connect with solely because of O. Russell's direction.But I feel the film lagged in the third act before finally coming to a close. The film feels like 3 hours rather than 2. It includes loads of excess that would have served the film better if it had been cut and left on the cutting room floor. I suggest removing a few nice but rather un-necessary scenes involving DiMaso and his boss (Played by Louis C.K) as well as a scene involving DiMaso at his home, which I felt did nothing to progress the story in anyway. O. Russell is a director who is overly talented but can't seem to leave anything out.The cast is what really makes this film glimmer. 'Christian Bale' coming off the success of the Batman Trilogy plays Irving. He performs the anger, confusion, and smarts that came with the character. He was able to move the story along. 'Amy Adams' shines as Sydney. Her fake British accent is perfect and her performance is remarkably convincing as the clever and decidedly beautiful woman. 'Bradley Cooper' surprisingly pulls off the dramatic role as the somewhat senile detective. I have to give him a tip of the hat, when I say he really puts some effort into the role, and overshadows Bale in the shots they share together. 'Jeremy Renner' plays the sweet mayor, and really pulls off the powerful and very much likable character he plays. I felt sorry for him at the end and felt Renner made the best of his screentime. Also during the end we get a very surprising (and delighting) uncredited cameo from 'Robert De'Niro' as a very powerful mob boss, who plays the tension high and convincing, and gave me a small smirk every time I saw him on screen.The costumes and hair styling is also pretty elegant. Sydney's curly hair is pretty fashionable to the period, and her flashy and scandalous clothing is quite beautiful to look at. Irving himself sports a nice hairdo, as does the agent, DiMaso in a short cut curly hairdo as well. The costumes were well selected and fit the period well. The hairdos were well done and also fit the period well and look really cool as well.All and All 'American Hustle' is a smart film with top notch performances, solid characters, great directing, and even if the film is a bit too long, it's still entertaining. B- 4/7/14'American Hustle' is rated R for pervasive language, some sexual content and brief violence. It's appropriate for ages 14 and up.

reviewText: David O Russell teams up again with actors from his previous films - Bradley Cooper, Jennifer Lawrence and uncredited Robert de Niro from Silver Linings Playbook; Christian Bale and Amy Adams from The Fighter. One thing is guaranteed - starring in a Russell movie will get you a nomination or a win at the various awards. (Melissa Leo won an Oscar for the Fighter - who can forget her acceptance speech?). This is no exception - apart from Robert de Niro's brief cameo, all four of the abovementioned actors have been nominated for Academy Awards for their roles in this movie, with a couple of award wins to date. With such a stellar cast, how can it miss?Christian Bale once again immerses himself fully into his character - con man Irving Rosenfeld - padding an extra 50 pounds onto his frame. His portrayal of the psychotic wraith Trevor Reznik in The Machinist, for which he lost 60 pounds was spellbinding. Robert de Niro's cameo as Victor Telegio was brilliant!But Jennifer Lawrence (Rosalyn Rosenfeld), an exceptionally versatile actress, is simply too young to be convincing in her role, despite her outstanding performance. She is 23, but could easily pass for 18. Amy Adams' (Sidney Tosser/Edith Greensley) inconsistent accent, can't make up its mind whether to be British or American (with even the occasional Aussie twang).  She does not switch easily between her twin roles. She is just too scrawny to exude sex appeal - her low cut dresses hint at boobs, not cleavage. The neurotic but ambitious Bradley Cooper as FBI agent Richie diMaso, with his tightly permed hair is so OTT as to degenerate into a caricature. His mannerisms are Jewish, his appearance Arabic/Jewish - he ain't no Italian! His hysterical temper tantrums, evident in Silver Linings Playbook, may stereotype him for future roles. The supporting cast did better overall, particularly Jeremy Renner's Mayor Carmine Polito and Louis C.K. as Cooper's much abused supervisor Stoddard Thorsen.Without spoilers, the movie is a sting operation, with con artists Bale and Adams being forced to team up with Cooper for immunity when they get caught red handed. Loosely based on the ABSCAM scandals of the 70s and 80s, it is drawn out, overwrought and failed to hold my attention, despite a few really funny throwaway scenes . At over 2 hours, it is too long.It just goes to show that despite a muddled plot, overlong scenes and some mediocre acting, not uncommonly the voters on The Oscars, Golden Globes, Baftas etc. clearly see merit where I don't. As always, far more deserving actors/movies are ignored out there. Joaquin Phoenix, despite numerous nominations, failed to win a single award for Walk the Line. Go figure. . .Watch it if you must, but in a week's time, you will have forgotten it.

reviewText: The bottom line about "American Hustle" is that for me, it was an uneven mix of drama and comedy as well as realism and escapism that left me scratching my head about what sort of movie its makers wanted it to be.  Another problem for me is the depiction of Christian Bale's character as a "nice conman" and making him the "hero" of the story and the FBI special agent as the (sort of) heavy.  Finally, the movie had a twist ending that I felt was wildly implausible and also completely dishonest with the movie's audience.I really did want to like the movie (it had a power cast who did well with their characters...especially Christian Bales and Bradley Cooper.  Jennifer Lawrence did well as Bale's ditz of a wife although I thought she was a tad too young in the role.  The general outline of the plot was also interesting.  It depicted through a fictional lens, the Abscam investigation where the FBI (using a confidence man it recruited) ultimately caught a number of corrupt politicians, including US Congressmen and a Senator.But I think it was a mistake to depict the story of the film from the perspective of the conman vice the FBI special agents, let alone show the FBI special agent who was his handler as an out-of-control drug abusing nutcase.  I found myself thinking, yeah, that's the way the real-life conman who Bale's character is modeled on (and who sold his "story" to the film-makers) probably remembers it, but I wonder how the FBI special agents (there were two handlers in real life) remember things.This leads me to another thing that I really hated about "American Hustle" and which the movie "Goodfellas" which it imitates in some ways did not have...I'm talking about the ultimate fate of the protagonist and the moronic twist ending that does not play fair with viewers.<spoilers for both "American Hustle" and "Goodfellas">In "Goodfellas," Henry Hill gets cornered by his own stupidity and greed and facing a long stretch in prison from the Feds or a bullet in the head from his former business associates, he becomes a cooperating witness.  His friends all go to jail and he survives, but the movie ends by showing him frustrated and lost somewhere in middle America far away from the New York milieu that was his home and his marriage over.Contrast that with the ending of "American Hustle."  The conman played by Bales suddenly has pangs of guilt over betraying a friend (the corrupt mayor of Camden).  So --and this is all done off-screen until the big "twist ending-- he manages to steal money the FBI was hoping to snare a mafia boss by staging a con against the FBI and his handler.  He then blackmails the FBI into going easy on his friend the mayor and giving him and his girlfriend a free ride on all the crimes they had committed.One thing I hated about that was the way it was all hidden until after the fact from us the viewers.  Maybe some people don't mind a movie or a book doing something like that but I hate it.  It's a cheap trick, and it's not playing fair with the audience.  They still could have shown the "lovable" conman scamming the FBI but the viewers should have known what was going on.(incidentally, in real life, the mayor did not get a light sentence at all but a very severe one; and the conman got very well-paid by the FBI for his work for them)Also, I just gagged a bit at the way the movie sanitized the rather grubby real-life story of the conman after the Abscam case ended.  Yes, he and his girlfriend reconciled but their marriage eventually failed (not too surprising when the people involved were professional liars and cheats).  And his wife (Lawrence's character) wound up killing herself not long after the Abscam case became public.  Showing the conman and his girlfriend ride off into the sunset at the end of "American Hustle" made me think of the ending of an even worse movie "Tequila Sunrise" (where Mel Gibson managed to look heroic as a major league drug dealer and wound up with the girlfriend and the loot and his freedom).<end spoilers>So in the end, "American Hustle" is worth seeing for some great performances and some laughs along the way.  But it's nowhere near as honest a film as "Goodfellas" was.
summary: A movie that is less than the sum of its parts

reviewText: While I do not necessarily think American Hustle will go down as one of the best movies ever, I do think it deserves the accolades it got for being one of the best of this year.  It is a fictionalized version of actual events, telling the story of two con artists in the late 1970s who get busted by the FBI and are forced to cooperate with them to take down politicians and mobsters.The movie is all about the characters and the acting.  It is a story where there are really no "good" people.  Although all the characters do have some good qualities to them, they are all also very flawed.  So there is really not anyone you truly get behind and root for.  In fact, the closest to a "hero" in the story is Renner's character, Carmine Polito.  I do think all the actors did a wonderful job.  Everyone was really playing a role different than anything they had done in the past, but in my opinion Amy Adams really stole the show.  She was great in every scene she was in whether she was being a British seductress or when she was emotionally vulnerable.  Jennifer Lawrence also did a great job as the bi-polar wife of Christian Bale's character who inserts herself into the operation.
